method.name: extend
method.description: After extending a given object, it will inherit the methods described in ActiveEvent.ObservableObject.

class.description: After calling ActiveEvent.extend(object), the given object will inherit the methods in this namespace. If the given object has a prototype (is a class constructor), the object's prototype will inherit these methods as well.

method.name: makeObservable
method.description: Wraps the given method_name with a function that will call the method, then trigger an event with the same name as the method. This can safely be applied to virtually any method, including built in Objects (Array.pop, etc), but cannot be undone.

method.name: notify
method.description: Triggers event_name with the passed arguments.

return-type.description: Array of return values, or false if $break was thrown by an observer.

method.name: observeMethod
method.description: Similiar to makeObservable(), but after the callback is called, the method will be returned to it's original state and will no longer be observable.

method.name: observeOnce
method.description: Works exactly like observe(), but will stopObserving() after the next time the event is fired.

return-type.description: The observer that was passed in will be wrapped, this generated / wrapped observer is returned.

method.name: stopObserving
method.description: Removes a given observer. If no observer is passed, removes all observers of that event. If no event is passed, removes all observers of the object.

property.name: adapter
property.description: null if no connection is active, or the class that created the connection.

property.name: ClassMethods
property.description: Contains all methods that will become available to ActiveRecord classes.

property.name: connection
property.description: null if no connection is active, or the connection object.

property.name: InstanceMethods
property.description: Contains all methods that will become available to ActiveRecord instances.

property.name: internalCounter
property.description: Tracks the number of records created.

method.name: connect
method.description: Must be called before using ActiveRecord. If the adapter requires arguments, those must be passed in after the type of adapter.

examples.example: ActiveRecord.connect(ActiveRecord.Adapters.JaxerSQLite,'path_to_database_file'); ActiveRecord.adapter == ActiveRecord.Adapters.JaxerSQLite; ActiveRecord.connection.executeSQL('SELECT * FROM sqlite_master'); //or you can have ActiveRecord try to auto detect the enviornment ActiveRecord.connect();

method.name: create
method.description: Creates an ActiveRecord class, returning the class and storing it inside ActiveRecord.Models [ model_name ] . model_name is a singularized, capitalized form of table name.

examples.example: var User = ActiveRecord.create('users'); var u = User.find(5);

parameter.name: readyCallback
parameter.description: Must be specified if running in asynchronous mode.

method.name: define
method.description: If the table for your ActiveRecord does not exist, this will define the ActiveRecord and automatically create the table.

examples.example: var User = ActiveRecord.define('users', { name: '', password: '', comment_count: 0, profile: { type: 'text', value: '' }, serializable_field: { } }); var u = User.create( { name: 'alice', serializable_field: { a : '1', b: '2'} });

parameter.name: fields
parameter.description: Should consist of column name, default value pairs. If an empty array or empty object is set as the default, any arbitrary data can be set and will automatically be serialized when saved. To specify a specific type, set the value to an object that contains a "type" key, with optional "length" and "value" keys.

parameter.name: readyCallback
parameter.description: Must be specified if running in asynchronous mode.

method.name: execute
method.description: Execute a SQL statement on the active connection. If the statement requires arguments they must be passed in after the SQL statement.

method.name: observe
method.description: Observe an event on all models. observer will be called with model_class, model_instance.

property.name: JaxerMySQL
property.description: Adapter for Jaxer configured with MySQL.

property.name: JaxerSQLite
property.description: Adapter for Jaxer configured with SQLite

property.name: Local
property.description: Adapter for browsers supporting a SQL implementation (Gears, HTML5).

class.description: Each generated class will inherit all of the methods in this class, in addition to the ones dynamically generated by finders, validators, relationships, or your own definitions.

method.name: addValidator
method.description: Adds the validator to the _validators array of a given ActiveRecord.Class.

method.name: average
method.description: options can contain all params that find() can

method.name: belongsTo
method.description: Sepcifies a 1<-1 relationship between models. The foreign key will reside in the declaring object.

examples.example: Comment.belongsTo('User', { counter: 'comment_count' //comment count must be a column in User }); var c = Comment.find(5); //each Comment instance will gain the following 3 methods c.getUser() c.buildUser() c.createUser()

parameter.name: related_model_name
parameter.description: Can be a plural or singular referring to the related table, the model name, or a reference to the model itself ("users","User" or User would all work).

method.name: build
method.description: Identical to calling create(), but does not save the record.

method.name: count
method.description: options can contain all params that find() can

examples.example: var u = User.create( { name: 'alice', password: 'pass' }); u.id //will now contain the id of the user

method.name: destroy
method.description: Deletes a given id (if it exists) WITHOUT calling any callbacks or validations on the record.

method.name: find
method.description: Find a given record, or multiple records matching the passed conditions.

examples.example: var user = User.find(5); //finds a single record var user = User.find( { first: true, where: { id: 5 } }); var users = User.find(); //finds all var users = User.find( { where: 'name = "alice" AND password = "' + md5('pass') + '"', order: 'id DESC' }); //using the where syntax below, the parameters will be properly escaped var users = User.find( { where: { name: 'alice', password: md5('pass') } order: 'id DESC' }); var users = User.find('SELECT * FROM users ORDER id DESC');

parameter.name: params
parameter.description: Can be an integer to try and find a record by id, a complete SQL statement String, or Object of params, params may contain: select: Array of columns to select (default [ '*' ] ) where: String or Object joins: String order: String limit: Number offset: Number synchronize: Boolean

return-type.description: If finding a single record, response will be Boolean false or ActiveRecord.Instance. Otherwise an Array of ActiveRecord.Instance s will be returned (which may be empty).

method.name: first
method.description: Returns the first record sorted by id.

method.name: hasMany
method.description: Sepcifies a 1->N relationship between models. The foreign key will reside in the child (related) object.

examples.example: User.hasMany('comments', { dependent: true }); var u = User.find(5); //each User instance will gain the following 5 methods u.createComment() u.buildComment() u.destroyComment() u.getCommentList() //takes the same options as find() u.getCommentCount() //takes the same options as count()

parameter.name: related_model_name
parameter.description: Can be a plural or singular referring to the related table, the model name, or a reference to the model itself ("users","User" or User would all work).

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Can contain { String } "foreignKey", { Boolean } "dependent", { String } "order" and { String } "where" keys.

method.name: hasOne
method.description: Sepcifies a 1->1 relationship between models. The foreign key will reside in the related object.

examples.example: User.hasOne(CreditCard); var u = User.find(5); //each User instance will gain the following 3 methods u.getCreditCard() u.buildCreditCard() u.createCreditCard()

parameter.name: related_model_name
parameter.description: Can be a plural or singular referring to the related table, the model name, or a reference to the model itself ("users","User" or User would all work).

method.name: last
method.description: Returns the last record sorted by id.

method.name: max
method.description: options can contain all params that find() can

method.name: min
method.description: options can contain all params that find() can

method.name: sum
method.description: options can contain all params that find() can

examples.example: Account.transaction(function() { var from = Account.find(2); var to = Account.find(3); to.despoit(from.withdraw(100.00)); });

parameter.name: proceed
parameter.description: The block of code to execute inside the transaction.

parameter.name: error
parameter.description: Optional error handler that will be called with an exception if one is thrown during a transaction. If no error handler is passed the exception will be thrown.

examples.example: Article.update(3, { title: 'New Title' }); //or pass an array of ids and an array of attributes Article.update( [ 5,7 ] , [ { title : 'Title for 5'}, { title : 'Title for 7'} ] );

parameter.name: updates
parameter.description: A string of updates to make, or a Hash of column value pairs.

parameter.name: conditions
parameter.description: Optional where condition, or Hash of column name, value pairs.

method.name: validatesLengthOf
method.description: Accepts "min" and "max" numbers as options.

class.description: Each found instance will inherit all of the methods in this class, in addition to the ones dynamically generated by finders, validators, relationships, or your own definitions.

method.name: destroy
method.description: Removes the object from the database, but does not destroy the object in memory itself.

method.name: get
method.description: Get a given key on the object. If your field name is a reserved word, or the name of a method (save, updateAttribute, etc) you must use the get() method to access the property. For convenience non reserved words (title, user_id, etc) can be accessed directly (instance.key_name)

method.name: keys
method.description: Returns an array of the column names that the instance contains.

method.name: reload
method.description: Loads the most current data for the object from the database.

method.name: save
method.description: Persists the object, creating or updating as nessecary.

method.name: set
method.description: Sets a given key on the object. You must use this method to set a property, properties assigned directly (instance.key_name = value) will not persist to the database and may cause errors.

method.name: stop
method.description: Stops the synchronization of the record with the database.

method.name: synchronize
method.description: Once synchronized a found instance will have it's values updated if other records with the same id change in the database.

method.name: toObject
method.description: Returns a "clean" version of the object, with just the data and no methods.

method.name: updateAttribute
method.description: Sets a given key on the object and immediately persists that change to the database without triggering callbacks or validation .

method.name: updateAttributes
method.description: Updates all of the passed attributes on the record and then calls save().

method.name: values
method.description: Returns an array of the column values that the instance contains.

method.name: current
method.description: Returns the current schema version number.

method.name: max
method.description: Returns the highest key name in the ActiveRecord.Migrations hash.

method.name: migrate
method.description: Migrates a database schema to the given version.

class.description: This object is passed to all migrations as the only parameter.

examples.example: ActiveRoutes maps URI strings to method calls, and visa versa. It shares a similar syntax to Rails Routing, but is framework agnostic and can map calls to any type of object. Server side it can be used to map requests for a given URL to a method that will render a page, client side it can be used to provide deep linking and back button / history support for your Ajax application. Declaring Routes ---------------- Wether declared in the constructor, or with addRoute(), routes can have up to three parameters, and can be declared in any of the follow ways: - "name", "path", { params } - "path", { params } - "path" The path portion of a route is a URI string. Parameters that will be passed to the method called are represented with a colon. Names are optional, but the path and the params together must declare "object" and "method" parameters. The following are all valid routes: var routes = new ActiveRoutes( [ [ 'root','/', { object : 'Pages',method:'index'}], [ 'contact','/contact', { object : 'Pages',method:'contact'}], [ 'blog','/blog', { object : 'Blog',method:'index'}], [ 'post','/blog/post/:id', { object : 'Blog',method:'post'}], [ '/pages/*', { object : 'Pages',method:'page'}], [ '/:object/:method' ] ] ,Application); Catch All Routes ---------------- If you want to route all requests below a certain path to a given method, place an asterisk in your route. When a matching path is dispatched to that route the path components will be available in an array called "path". route_set.addRoute('/wiki/*', { object : 'WikiController',method:'page'}) route_set.dispatch('/wiki/a/b/c'); //calls: WikiController.page( { object : 'WikiController',method:'page',path:['a','b','c']}) Scope ----- You can specify what scope an ActiveRoutes instance will look in to call the specified objects and methods. This defaults to window but can be specified as the second parameter to the constructor. Generating URLs --------------- The method urlFor() is available on every route set, and can generate a URL from an object. Using the routes declared in the example above: routes.urlFor( { object : 'Blog',method:'post',id:5}) == '/blog/post/5'; If named routes are given, corresponding methods are generated in the passed scope to resolve these urls. Application.postUrl( { id : 5}) == '/blog/post/5'; To get the params to generate a url, a similar method is generated: Application.postParams( { id : 5}) == {object:'Blog',method:'post',id:5}; To call a named route directly without round-tripping to a string and back to params use: Application.callPost( { id : 5}); Dispatching ----------- To call a given method from a URL string, use the dispatch() method. routes.dispatch('/'); //will call Pages.index() routes.dispatch('/blog/post/5'); //will call Blog.post( { id : 5}); History ------- Most server side JavaScript implementations will not preserve objects between requests, so the history is not of use. Client side, after each dispatch, the route and parameters are recorded. The history itself is accessible with the "history" property, and is traversable with the next() and back() methods.

return-type.description: options can contain the following keys: - base: default '', the default path / url prefix to be used in a generated url - dispatcher: default ActiveRoutes.prototype.defaultDispatcher, the dispatcher function to be called when dispatch() is called and a route is found - camelizeObjectName: default true, if true, trying to call "blog_controller" through routes will call "BlogController" - camelizeMethodName: default true, if true, trying to call "my_method_name" through routes will call "myMethodName" - camelizeGeneratedMethods: default true, will export generated methods into the scope as "articleUrl" instead of "article_url"

property.name: defaultDispatcher
property.description: If no "dispatcher" key is passed into the options to contstruct a route set this is used. It will call scope.object_name.method_name(route.params)

method.name: addRoute
method.description: Add a new route to the route set.

method.name: back
method.description: Calls to the previous dispatched route in the history.

method.name: dispatch
method.description: Will match() the given path and call the dispatcher if one is found.

examples.example:
var routes = new ActiveRoutes( [ [ 'post','/blog/post/:id', { object : 'blog',method: 'post'}]]);
routes.dispatch('/blog/post/5');
//by default calls Blog.post( { object : 'blog',method: 'post',id: 5});

method.name: getError
method.description: If match() returns false, the error it generates can be retrieved with this function.

examples.example:
var route = routes.match('/blog/post/5');
route == { object : 'blog',method: 'post', id: 5};

return-type.description: false if no match, otherwise the matching route.

method.name: next
method.description: Calls to the next dispatched route in the history if back() has already been called.

examples.example:
var routes = new ActiveRoutes( [ [ 'post','/blog/post/:id', { object : 'blog',method: 'post'}]]);
routes.urlFor( { object : 'blog',method: 'post', id: 5}) == '/blog/post/5';

class.description: Provides a number of methods from the Prototype.js framework, without modifying any built in prototypes to ensure compatibility and portability.

method.name: arrayFrom
method.description: Returns an array from an array or array like object.

method.name: bind
method.description: Emulates Prototype's Function.prototype.bind

parameter.name: object
parameter.description: object will be in scope as "this" when func is called.

method.name: block
method.description: If it is the last argument of current function is a function, it will be returned. You can optionally specify the number of calls in the stack to look up.

method.name: camelize
method.description: Emulates Prototype's String.prototype.camelize

method.name: clone
method.description: Emulates Prototype's Object.clone

method.name: curry
method.description: Emulates Prototype's Function.prototype.curry.

method.name: extend
method.description: Emulates Prototype's Object.extend

method.name: getGlobalContext
method.description: Returns the global context object (window in most implementations).

method.name: indexOf
method.description: Emulates Array.indexOf for implementations that do not support it.

method.name: keys
method.description: Returns an array of keys from an object.

method.name: log
method.description: Logs a message to the available logging resource. Accepts a variable number of arguments.

method.name: proc
method.description: If the value passed is a function the value passed will be returned, otherwise a function returning the value passed will be returned.

method.name: underscore
method.description: Emulates Prototype's String.prototype.underscore

method.name: value
method.description: If the value passed is a function, the function is called and the value returned, otherwise the value passed in is returned.

method.name: without
method.description: Returns an array without the given item.

class.description: A port of Rails Inflector class.

method.name: ordinalize
method.description: Generates an orginalized version of a number as a string (9th, 2nd, etc)

method.name: pluralize
method.description: Generates a plural version of an english word.

method.name: singularize
method.description: Generates a singular version of an english word.

class.description: Provides JSON support if a native implementation is not available.
